I have been playing this game for years now. After trying many different simulators, I can affirm that BeamNG.drive is the best of them all. The Reason? The Physics engine. Because the physics engine has been build from the ground up, the driving and crashing physics of this game are out of this world. The risk of destroying your car makes this the most educational and  realistic driving simulator available. Let me explain.

I love racing rally with games like Dirt Rally 1 and 2, and they have fantastically fleshed out maps and co-driver calls. However, when I crash in the Dirt Rally games, even in really bad crashes, it feels more like a slight annoyance than a bone-shattering defeat. Here in Beam, every move counts, every gear shift, every turn of the wheel, every handbrake... Because if you slam that car into anything you will feel the repercussions, and you may not even finish the course in one piece. For those interested in rally, I would recommend getting mods in the repository, as there are modders who have integrated co-driver calls into the game.
The result of the amazing physics is that if you slam a tree while rallying at 90 mph, you will be wrapped around that tree. If you lightly roll your car, you will have some dents and cosmetic damage but will be able to finish the course in one piece. 

I originally started the game with a keyboard and mouse, then I moved up to a controller, then a non-force feedback sim wheel, and then finally and force-feedback wheel called the Thrustmaster T150 Pro. Having a force-feedback wheel has given me real-life transferable skills. I was able to go from never driving a manual transmission vehicle in my life, to getting in one and being able to drive it mostly because of what I learned in BeamNG. I am a much better driver in real life than I used to be could be, all because of this game. Other simulators can give me fun, but only this game could give me those types of transferable skills.

From the custom car creation, to the modding community with amazing vehicles and maps, to the decent AI system, to the no in-app-purchases/DLC, to the scenarios, I have had a plethora of fun in this game.

My one desperate request is for rallying, along with co-driver calls to be put in the base game.

P.S. The team at "BeamMP" (Beam Multii-player) have a great peer-to-peer multiplayer mod of Beam, which is something that I always dreamed of.

TL;DR If you want to cruise around, test your skills on a track, tune cars and crash them into stuff, by all means buy this game without even thinking about it. If you want a sense of purpose and linearity, rewards for doing stuff -- don't, it's a sandbox.

I love this game for what it is --a sandbox car simulator. It simulates EVERYTHING in the car, from the alternator to the goddamn tire deformity. But that's it, there's no purpose, no sense of progression nothing. It's a sandbox simulator for cars where you can do anything the physics simulation allows. The game will help you a lot if you want to:
-Learn how a car works
-Learn how to drive in real life
-Understand the parts of a car
-Understand the physics that govern a real life car

BUT if you want to get a car and do missions, have a story with progression, then bad news, it can't help you. There is a career mode but it's very experimental. As of right now, it's nothing more than a set of errands, divided in 4 skills (delivery, racing, off-roading and specialised stuff like police), where if you crash your car you have to pay a lot of money for repairs or wait a real life time limit for the insurance to fix your car for a fee. It's fun, but wears off real quick --I got to max level delivery within a day and bought a truck to haul bigger freight and earn more money, but it's more of the same.

In Freeroam you have a couple of missions but they're hardly a challenge because the AI racers are really stupid and crash all the time. The ones you race solo are also not a challenge, even if you're playing on a keyboard like I am.

All in all, I still recommend it and still play it a lot (I reached the 100 hour mark within a forthnight). Even my potato laptop runs it, with very low FPS but enough to not make it infuriating. There's a bug with the vehicle triggers for opening doors, boots, bonnets though, where they simply vanish and support couldn't help me. Probably due to my rig, but I tried on the same laptop running Zorian (linux) and the triggers worked.

TL;DR: Buy it! ...If you drive, do not even think about it. Just do it.

---

2000 Km in 3 days.

Ever since NFS 1 I was dreaming about a game where we can drive in traffic. Nothing for many years (eg. Midtown Madness, NFS: Run) didn't even match NFS 1 (I didn't see Forza). Now, we can drive in traffic in this game - and it has wonderful synergy with the realistic damage model. Yes, you can immediately repair with a button when you freeroam - but when you play the garage->garage scenario, where you have a series (endless if you want) of different cars that you are tasked to move from spot to spot on the map, you have not the liberty of repair. And boy - you start to think whether you should risk the overtake or not. (And some of the cars in the traffic are even amazingly annoying - when they e.g. stop for 10 seconds, or even brake just in front of you in higher speed.)

The abovementioned scenario - it is really great when you switch cars seamlessly after each delivery & you can experience and enjoy them. Every car is different.

Which is also true for gearboxes. Newer cars let's you shift classicaly with wheel paddles (semi-automatic), a lot of "american-like" cars have automatic, but lo and behold: some cars have manual ...& you really drive stick here! Well, I don't have the stick per-se, so I use paddles - but this is [my] first game where you need to use clutch to shift! (Otherwise it kills the motor - sometime it just switches off, sometimes it gets damage.) Manual gearbox and swifting with paddles and cluch is sick as XXX! :)) And it is fabulous, when these three modes change randomly with the car you are getting. Sometimes you have tranquil drive in low powered automatic truck, sometimes you have old manual racer.

I realized it today BTW - that you can switch off clutch/throttle shift assistants. Without them, it is magical. IRL I already also drive automatic, but manual shifting with clutch is nice nostalgia and good challenge (that because I am used to drive exclusively left-foot-brake + right-foot-throttle... now I need to dance on the pedals a lot more :D).

There is a lot of off-road cars - and I had really amazing experience with garage->garage with off-road cars (with traffic) - I have view from hood & the delivery task starts always under the roof - I didn't know what I was driving! :D Is it a truck? Is it a big truck? (Like do I push the cars out of my way big :D?) Or small off-road cart or something? Or something hellishly overpowered? Maybe random experience (not designed like that), amazing never the less.

It works in Linux!

About that "overpowered" - in the above mentioned mode, you sometimes get to drive a dragster, too. The insanity & the focus you need to have not to crash it in hellish speed right away. (Dragster like car that turns normally, brakes considerably sub-par ...and accelerates to 300 Km/h in a few seconds!)

With comparison with my favorite Dirt Rally 1: in Dirt Rally I feel somewhat more what the car is doing via force feedback - there I feel whether the car wants to steer more or less via force-feedback (which e.g. greatly helps when performing Scandinavian flick & also overall). But maybe I have something wrong in my system (or game settings ...3 days, mind you :) ).

Also the simulation - the physical model seems more detailed in Dirt Rally 1 (how the car behaves in various conditions/situations), but not by much. 

What is also beautiful in BeamNG.drive is that you can tune all your cars in detail.

One more about the destruction model in BeamNG.drive: it is quite worth it to drive carefully and slowly in some spots, but as I usually do not exactly, I often stand before the challange of making the rest of the way (up to 4 Km) with damaged car. Something this is serious - missing wheel or stuck somehow. Lost focus, wrecked a buggy (both front semiaxes destroyed), totally not going forward ...but I realized it goes somewhat fine in reverse (there was some steering & I made it succesfully). Another nice experience. ... Or sometimes you just stuck with other car -> fun.

The game is a big sandbox - you can free roam on relatively big islands, even when you do a delivery in garage->garage & it is an interesting car, you can take it for a ride anywhere. But like - can you not wreck it completely while wandering, so you can finally deliver at the end? :D

It looks that the game is modable. Like very modable. I was not researching outside, but the game allows you to download many different things from repository - which look like made by community and not developers. This includes even whole islands! New cars, new settings for probably everything including car tunings, new challenges. There is some community mod - scenario that was saying something about different traffic & which was throwing LUA errors. Seeing LUA being used in a game is always a good sign. ;) Can you script how traffic will behave? That is bordering insane! :) Like this is my wet dream - doing research how people behave in real traffic in critical situations & then put it into computer simulator where players will be able to experience that. Learn how to drive to avoid collisions with cars that are really behaving like people do. ;)

& I heard there is multiplayer, too! :)

What I saw here in my 2 Mm is "insanely good" and worth for me 100 EUR and more. :) Also it is still in development - so it is bound to improve still.

Rating: ★★★★★

BeamNG.drive, developed by BeamNG GmbH, stands as a testament to the pinnacle of vehicular simulation and sandbox gaming. From realistic crash physics to the sheer breadth of customization and open-world exploration, this game offers a one-of-a-kind experience that caters to both simulation enthusiasts and casual gamers alike.

The driving physics in BeamNG.drive are unparalleled, setting a new standard for realism in the genre. Every vehicle reacts dynamically to terrain, weight distribution, and impact forces, providing an incredibly immersive and authentic driving experience. The attention to detail in the physics engine allows for a wide range of vehicles, from sedans to trucks, to handle with precision and nuance.

The game's sandbox mode is a playground for automotive enthusiasts, offering an expansive open world with diverse terrains to explore. Whether you're cruising down highways, tackling off-road trails, or simply pushing your vehicle to its limits on the test track, the freedom to experiment and push the boundaries is at the core of BeamNG.drive's appeal.

One of the standout features is the realistic damage modeling. Collisions are not just cosmetic; they impact the vehicle's functionality in a true-to-life manner. Witnessing your car crumple and deform in response to crashes is both awe-inspiring and a testament to the game's commitment to authenticity.

BeamNG.drive also boasts an active and passionate modding community, contributing a wealth of user-generated content. From new vehicles and maps to gameplay enhancements, the modding scene significantly expands the game's already extensive content and adds to its replay value.

The vehicle customization options are comprehensive, allowing players to tweak and fine-tune every aspect of their cars, from engine performance to aesthetic details. This level of control empowers players to create unique vehicles tailored to their preferences and experiment with various configurations.

While the lack of a structured career or mission mode might be considered a drawback for those seeking a more guided experience, the open-ended nature of BeamNG.drive encourages creativity and self-driven exploration.

In conclusion, BeamNG.drive is a triumph in vehicular simulation, offering an unrivaled level of realism and freedom for players to explore, experiment, and enjoy the intricacies of driving. Whether you're a dedicated simulation enthusiast or simply someone looking for an engaging and visually stunning sandbox experience, BeamNG.drive is a must-play title that delivers on its promise of realistic, dynamic, and endlessly entertaining vehicular mayhem.

According to the store page, it's [i]A dynamic soft-body physics vehicle simulator capable of doing just about anything[/i]. But the question that remains is: what [i]does it[/i] want to do?

Currently it feels like a car crash simulator with a bad user interface, rather mediocre graphics, not-so-great performance, some bugs, and nothing really to do. The hand drawn mini cut scenes in the mini campaigns are awful, and the tasks are, sorry, just stupid.

Sure, driving a car down a cliff and watching the damage model deform it is fun 3 times, maybe 5 times. But what then? The damage model may be great, but the driving does not feel great, neither in a rally car on gravel, nor in a race car on tarmac. I wouldn't mind the current state if it was in early access for half a year, but it's been quite a while. And even though updates  are coming regularly, it seems to me like it would take them ages to turn this into a polished product.

Yes, there are a ton of mods which mainly add more cars (obviously you are not allowed to add licensed/real ones), but they do not solve the problem: it's not that it lacks cars. Also some of the more interesting mods I found referenced on the internet (e.g., adding real race tracks like Nürburgring) seem to be gone by now, maybe because their authors did not update them or for copyright reasons since they were taken from other games, I do not know.

To be honest I expected something [i]a lot[/i] better from the reviews here on Steam. I guess people just like crashing cars a lot more than properly driving them?

EDIT: To be fair, I also need to mention something positive. What I really like in the game is driving the 4WD cars with high suspension offroad, e.g., on the figure eight dirt track, or in freeroam mode on the Italy map. You can properly switch between 2WD mode, 4WD high, 4WD low, and separately lock/unlock the front and read differentials, which allows for some great hill climbing. The environment and surface simulation is good but not overly realistic, e.g., you can just drive into the soft sand on the beach with full tire pressure in 2WD mode, stop, then floor it in M1 gear, and be fine instead of sinking into the sand in any way. or to put it another way: the environment affects your car, but not the other way around (no sand or rocks move, only your car does). But overall it's fun.

EDIT2: There are some good mods out there, and nice maps for rock crawling and drifting. I hate drifting and I'm not that much of a rock crawler, but you will like the game if you're into one of these. If you get this game, be prepared to spend some time on finding the mods you want to play. The base game is not gonna cut it. [h2]7/10[/h2]

While a very simple concept, in practice, the developers of this game honestly deserve an award. The base game, while limited, still offers an extremely wide variety of vehicles, customizations, tests, missions, etc and the terrains are even better. The developers, "BeamNG" are extremely active in updating the game with new features and support, as-well as following a very thorough regiment of patches and Beam has always been very active with the community itself unlike very many other titles which seem to presently follow the "cashgrab" ideology. It is still in Early Access and over time I have clocked 4370 hours (check my profile, its true) on this game so I am very very excited to see where this game goes in the future! Being the very first game I personally installed, I have watched it evolve from a simple soft body physics engine with a small map and even smaller fan-base, I have nothing but respect for the developer having transformed that into what it is today! The engine it runs on is one of, if not the, most impressive soft body physics based system I have ever seen. Dynamic nodes that respond not only to impact but also have physical properties themselves such as weight distribution, tensile strength, and very well coded positioning. One topic I always touch on is the modding community and need I even mention it? Not only is there an extremely active modding community, but with that, the developers make every tool and asset necessary readily available! Now, as I mentioned previously, I have clocked quite a few hours in this game, and only have one TINY concern that doesn't affect play-ability or my gaming experience in any way shape or form which is the tires. I'm sure a lot of players know if you hold left Ctrl you can grab individual nodes on the vehicles themselves, some of which being the tires. If you rip them apart the wrong way, they will stretch across the screen and be a bit of a nuisance. Im sure its a very complicated issue that will be sorted and I recommend that the soft physics of the tires being limited to punctures and dynamic nodes that disconnect from the wheels themselves like a bead on a real tire but the concern is only because of it being a slight annoyance.. After clocking thousands of hours in a game and having only one small issue, this is most certainly a very very impressive title and I will definitely be sticking around until the release and later. Thanks a bunch Beam for creating such a vastly immersive and almost addicting game! 10/10 -W.G

[h1] BeamNG.drive: free updates, car crashes and much more [/h1]
Please note that I play BeamNG.drive on a wheel, my G923, with force feedback and trueforce enabled of course.
Where should I even start?

[h2] The crashes [/h2]
This is pretty much what everybody knows BeamNG for; Its crash simulation. Yet, this game isn't only a crash simulator, there is way more to it. But the crashes are pretty much what you see it the videos. Tyres can pop, the hood can come off, headlights can break, I forget to press the clutch and grind my gears until they are completely broken, you know.

[h2] The Things You Drive [/h2]
Or, The Cars. If you didn't know for some reason, BeamNG.drive doesn't have licensed cars. Instead, we have cars like the Ibishu Pigeon and Civetta Bolide. The cars are detailed, most have openable doors, hoods and trunks. The car amount isn't very mind-blowing when there's games with more than 500 cars, standing at 36 cars (0.31), though there are many configurations of each car.

[h2] The Things You Drive On [/h2]
Or, The Maps. BeamNG.drive has 15 different maps. All of them are detailed and most are fun to explore in my opinion. Some of the most fun I've had playing this game (and I'm not kidding) was from driving around with no direction in West Coast USA.
The map I liked the most was either West Coast USA or Italy. 

[h2] The Things That Make Your Steering Wheel Turn By Itself [/h2]
Or in other words, The Force Feedback/Vibration. I don't really have anything to say about the vibration with a controller, since I have always played with a wheel. The Force Feedback with a wheel is a bit different than with other games, at least in my opinion. The force feedback sometimes is smooth, but most times it feels like its trying to vibrate the steering wheel instead of turning it, at least it sounds like it. (This is my experience though, yours might be different.)

[h2] The Things You Can Do [/h2]
There's a lot of stuff to do in BeamNG.drive, and I mean a Lot. There's scenarios, kind of like missions you can complete (its in the name), there's campaigns, which are like a career modes but short (and they don't save for some reason), there's light runner, where you can drive in the sky in weird tracks and hope to not fall off, there's time trials, you probably know what those are, there's the garage, where you can look at your car, there's the bus routes, where you can imagine you are playing a bus simulator, there's the track builder, where you can build tracks and then there is the career mode, which at the time of writing this, is coming soon. And then there also is the button I probably used the most, Freeroam. Basically it lets you drive freely in the maps and mess around. [b] You can even spawn traffic, which is fun to drive with. [/b]

[h2] The Things You Hear [/h2]
Or, The Sounds and The Soundtrack. Yeah, no, BeamNG.drive doesn't have soundtrack. Except for a lightrunner, which has it's own music. The car sounds are pretty good, the cars even have sounds for opening doors.

[h2] The Things You Get Free Content With [/h2]
Or, The Free Updates. BeamNG.drive was released to steam on the 29 of march in 2015, and it still gets free updates. Stuff like this is very rare, since most racing games just get a sequel and then another and another, but BeamNG is still getting free updates, without any DLC.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
BeamNG.drive is a massive game which is constantly being improved with free update and content. It also has mod support with an in-game repository to download mods from. BeamNG.drive will be even better when the career mode is finished, if it is good. For now, I would give BeamNG.drive a [b] 9/10 [/b]. Now that you have read this review, I recommend you to read other reviews too, because most of this review was just my own opinion. Thank you.

Finally there is next to nothing to actually do outside of campaigns and time trials. Maybe its me but crashing cars over and over loses its appeal fast. There is a "work in progress" career mode that is also pain. If you fender bender your car it will take rel time to fix it. In a game where crashing is a huge chunk of what you do, that is a problem. Its a sandbox and while that floats some peoples boats, it doesn't float mine. I don't play games for memes and am frankly not creative or patient enough to deal with the tedious track builder.

Its got the bones of a game but not the flesh. Right now I cant recommend this game even at its modest price point. There is simply not enough there. I'm sure mods help but devs shouldnt rely on modders to make their game passable.

Game Title: BeamNG.drive
User Opinion:
Thrillingly realistic, a must-have for any simulation aficionado.

Review:
Title: A Masterpiece of Physics and Realism
BeamNG.drive stands out in the simulation genre, offering an unparalleled experience of driving realism and soft-body physics. This game goes beyond traditional racing, providing a sandbox environment where every crash, bump, and turn feels genuinely lifelike.

Running on a high-end system with specifications such as an AMD Ryzen 9 7950X CPU, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090 GPU, and 32 GB of RAM, BeamNG.drive performs exceptionally. The game's intricate physics and detailed vehicle damage are rendered flawlessly, showcasing the power of such a setup. With settings maxed out at a 3840 x 2160 resolution, the graphical fidelity is nothing short of breathtaking, offering immersive landscapes and incredibly realistic vehicle models.

System Specifications:
OS: Microsoft Windows 11 Home, Version 10.0.22621 Build 22621
CPU: AMD Ryzen 9 7950X 16-Core Processor, 4501 Mhz, 16 Core(s), 32 Logical Processor(s)
GPU: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090, 31.0.15.3141
RAM: 32 GB
Resolution: 3840 x 2160 x 59 hertz
The game's performance on this setup was impeccable, with smooth frame rates even during the most intense crashes and physics simulations. The level of detail in each vehicle's deformation and the game's environments is a testament to BeamNG.drive's advanced simulation capabilities.

Gameplay:
BeamNG.drive offers an expansive range of vehicles and environments, allowing for endless experimentation. From serene drives through lush countrysides to high-speed crashes on intricate race tracks, the game caters to all kinds of players. The soft-body physics engine is the star, providing realistic damage and driving dynamics that respond accurately to every action.

Graphics and Audio:
The visual presentation is stunning, with detailed environments and vehicles that show off the game's physics engine. The audio is equally impressive, with realistic sound effects that enhance the immersive experience. Each vehicle sounds distinct, and the environmental sounds add a layer of depth to the gameplay.

Final Thoughts:
BeamNG.drive is a technical marvel that offers an unmatched simulation experience. It's a game where creativity and destruction coalesce into endless entertainment. Whether you're a simulation veteran or a newcomer to the genre, BeamNG.drive is a journey worth taking, especially on a system capable of unlocking its full visual and physical potential.

BeamNG.drive is a vehicle simulation video game developed and published by Bremen-based video game developer BeamNG. BeamNG.drive is an astounding driving game that redefines realism. Its soft-body physics engine meticulously simulates every vehicle component in real-time, delivering an incredibly authentic driving experience. Even if you're not typically into driving simulators, this game might just change your mind.

Why BeamNG.drive?

Soft-body Physics: The game's physics engine sets the standard for vehicle simulation. Crashes feel shockingly real, thanks to a precise damage model.

Vehicle Variety: With numerous customizable vehicles at your disposal, you can fine-tune everything from wheels and suspension to engines. The level of control is impressive.

Diverse Environments: Explore 12 expansive open-world environments, each with its own unique terrain. Whether you're navigating tropical jungles or racing on urban streets, the possibilities are endless.

More Features:

Game Modes: Beyond typical driving simulations, BeamNG.drive offers a wide range of gameplay options. From delivery missions to creating your own maps, the variety is exceptional.

Free Roam: Unleash your creativity in this mode. Modify environmental conditions and objects to customize your driving experience. Alter wind speeds or gravity for added challenges.

Scenarios: Enjoy a plethora of scenarios catering to all driving enthusiasts. Whether you're delivering cargo or evading police, the realistic physics engine immerses you in each experience.

Time Trials: Test your skills against the clock. Choose a vehicle, environment, and route, and compete to improve your best time.

Modding and Community Content: Join a vibrant community of enthusiasts who create unique vehicles, terrains, and scenarios. The modding capabilities are extensive, allowing you to personalize your game.

Automation Integration: Export your custom cars and engines from Automation, the car company tycoon game, into BeamNG.drive for a seamless experience.

Freedom: BeamNG.drive stands out for its player freedom. It's not just about vehicles; it's about creating your ideal driving scenario in an expansive open world. The combination of top-notch physics, endless customization, and a tight-knit community makes it the ultimate vehicle simulator.

**Creamy Chicken Alfredo Pasta**

**Ingredients:**

- 8 oz (about 225g) fettuccine pasta
- 1 lb (about 450g) boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into bite-sized pieces
- Salt and black pepper to taste
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
- 4 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 cup heavy cream
- 1 cup grated Parmesan cheese
- 1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese
- 1/2 cup unsalted butter
- 1 teaspoon garlic powder
- 1 teaspoon onion powder
- 1 teaspoon dried Italian herbs (optional)
- Chopped fresh parsley for garnish

**Instructions:**

1. Cook the fettuccine pasta according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.

2. Season the chicken pieces with salt and black pepper to taste.

3. In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium-high heat. Add the seasoned chicken and cook until browned and cooked through. Remove the chicken from the skillet and set aside.

4. In the same skillet, add minced garlic and cook for about 1 minute until fragrant.

5. Reduce the heat to medium-low, and add the heavy cream, butter, Parmesan cheese, mozzarella cheese, garlic powder, onion powder, and dried Italian herbs (if using). Stir continuously until the cheeses melt and the sauce is smooth and creamy.

6. Add the cooked chicken back to the skillet, stirring to combine. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes to heat the chicken through.

7. Toss the cooked fettuccine pasta into the creamy Alfredo sauce, ensuring it is well coated.

8. Season with additional salt and black pepper if needed. 

9. Garnish with chopped fresh parsley.

10. Serve immediately, and enjoy your super creamy and cheesy Chicken Alfredo Pasta!

This indulgent dish is rich, flavorful, and perfect for satisfying your cravings for creamy pasta.

Subject: Frustration Beyond Limits - An Angry Review for BeamNG.drive

Rating: 1/5 Stars

I feel compelled to express my overwhelming disappointment and sheer frustration with BeamNG.drive. From the outset, this game seemed promising, with its touted realistic physics and detailed vehicle damage modeling. However, my experience has been nothing short of infuriating.

Let's start with the controls—utterly abysmal. Maneuvering vehicles in this game is like trying to herd cats on roller skates. The sensitivity is through the roof, and the lack of responsiveness turns every attempt at precision driving into a chaotic mess. Whoever designed the control scheme must have taken sadistic pleasure in watching players struggle.

And what's with the lack of a decent tutorial? I found myself thrust into a world of confusion, attempting to decipher the game mechanics with no guidance whatsoever. Trial and error may work for some, but not for those of us who value our time and sanity.

The graphics, touted as a highlight, are a mixed bag. Sure, the vehicle models are detailed, but the environments are lackluster and uninspiring. The overall visual experience left me wondering if I had somehow transported back to the early 2000s.

Now, let's address the so-called "realistic physics." Realistic for what, a bizarro world where cars behave like drunk turtles on ice? The collisions, touted as the game's main attraction, are nothing more than a clumsy spectacle. There's a thin line between realistic physics and a carnival sideshow, and BeamNG.drive crosses it with flying colors.

The complete lack of engaging content is the final nail in the coffin. The scenarios and missions are as dull as dishwater, providing little motivation to endure the aggravation of the gameplay.

In conclusion, BeamNG.drive is a textbook example of a game that over-promises and under-delivers. It's a frustrating, time-wasting exercise in patience, and I cannot, in good conscience, recommend it to anyone seeking an enjoyable gaming experience. Save yourself the headache and invest your time and money elsewhere.

Every vehicle feels so characterful and unique - plus it literally does trucks so much better than Euro Truck Simulator almost by accident. Lovely tool to mess around with. Target audience? Perhaps those who like tools like Garry's mod but want a game with easy menu UI that can be operated with a game pad and a general theme that revolves around cars. 

Intrigued by my Summer Car but don't want any of that grind with engines and instead drive? Yes this is for you. Interested in different setups for a car model or interested in particular real life car models on how they look like / break apart as a soft physics model in the sim? This is for you. 

Lots of mods in form of tracks, car models and different setups and kits for said cars. Mod scene is weird, i see lots of passionate talk about level of quality on mods and how realistic some models look or don't look.  If none of this interests you then consider again. Quality of course varies but there is lot of the stuff. 

This game replaces nothing on the existing racing game scene, it instead occupies it's own niche slot and because of that i recommend getting it pretty openly to many but it requires at least rudimentary interest in messing around with cars and spending time checking out scenarios and mods and just spending time with the product to unlock it's potential. Devs have included some campaigns for achievements and scenarios and there is good support for wheels (Driving is nice with game pad too) but it's obvious the first requirement from the player is interest into the various topics presented in the game and spending time to find the fun parts. Nothing is served on a force fed silver plate. You choose what you want to do.

All in all a good product. Get it if you find yourself intrigued and have enough time and interest to explore.  Do not be scared of the Early Access tag. This product is very far into development at this stage (1/2024) and i have had no issues whatsoever.

BeamNG.drive brings realistic vehicle physics to the table, promising an authentic driving experience. However, the initial excitement tends to fizzle out after just a couple of hours, leaving players looking for reasons to stick around.

While the game aims for realism in its graphics, the visuals fall a bit short in terms of keeping you engaged. The environments lack the detailed touch found in other games, and despite the attempt at realism, they might not hold your interest for the long haul.

One of the game's highlights is its commitment to lifelike physics, providing a genuine driving feel. Yet, this feature, unfortunately, doesn't translate into sustained enjoyment. The lack of structured missions or incentives becomes apparent, making the open-world environment lose its charm rather quickly.

The controls, while adding to the realistic vibe, can be a bit challenging for newcomers. This authenticity, however, might turn into a hurdle, potentially causing frustration instead of enjoyment.

Despite the expansive open-world setting, the absence of compelling content becomes noticeable after a brief playthrough. The dearth of missions or progression systems leaves you without a clear goal, resulting in a somewhat monotonous experience.

While the variety in the vehicle selection is a plus, the limited customization options and overall lack of content might leave you wanting more. If you're interested, it might be worth considering picking up BeamNG.drive on sale – it's a short-lived taste of realism that could be enjoyable for a brief period, especially for driving enthusiasts.

Most unique, brilliant and captivating gaming experience ever. Evokes a sweet nostalgia for Midtown Madness and World Racing, especially the latter. Provides a stellar driving experience along a very wide spectrum. Exploring only 1% of the game can provide dozens of hours of nuanced play. Extracting more requires autonomy, exploration, experimentation, creativity, knowledge and skill.

Building your own variants for different applications, tuning them and putting them to the test under various conditions is a dream come true. As a lifelong sim racer, most of my time in this game is spent doing time trials so this aspect of the game is truly mind blowing.
But I must admit that I am shocked at how many hours I've spent doing bus routes as well. I very much enjoy the fact that I can switch from intensely furious racing to soothing and relaxing driving. 

Learning to use the World Editor and the various sub-editors within to create your own challenges is difficult and confusing at the beginning but it is a part of the natural progression. It requires a lot of patience, testing and exploration of the directory's file and folder structure but when learned, it becomes easy to use and considerably widens the scope of possibilities. Bus lines, AI races and time trials are by far the most exciting.

Racing sims have this rare quality of being pure and devoid of trivial distractions or superficialities. They are in a category of their own. Some are almost eternal. BeamNG may not be quite as pure and well oriented as truer racing sims, but it comes very close to providing that same feeling of driving on a knife edge, with the car unstable and the engine roaring magnificently. And with the freedom and range of operation that it offers...WOW...

In today's world where seemingly every AAA modern racing game seems to be all inspiration and no innovation, BeamNG.drive is a game that I keep coming back to because it's just so damn fun to play around with. 

Yes, the crash physics are the main appeal, but they add an element of difficulty that no other Sim-Racer can compete with: True level mechanical damage. Once you start realizing how delicate racing a car can be, it really changes your driving style to be more precise and careful when you're doing the races on the free-roam maps. 

I find myself having to restart a race multiple times before I can cross the finish line, but instead of getting frustrated with having to restart the race every time, I am always in awe at the damage models of the cars every time I wreck, most of the time on purpose. This level of detail will never be matched by any games with licensed cars, as that's a big no-no from a marketing perspective for many car brands.

Fortunately, BeamNG really has a fantastic modding community that only gets bigger with each passing day that more people find out about this game. If you're looking to get started with crashing various real world cars, you can check out the newly established BeamMods dot com, which also includes leaked paid mods as well.

A few years ago, I remember seeing somewhere that the Devs said it would be impossible to have this game running on multiplayer because of all the crash data it has to send across the servers. Today, you can download BeamMP and this dream suddenly becomes a wonderful reality. I love the fact that you can also drive your modded cars on these servers and if you and your friend have the same mod files installed, you can see each others cars in game. 

Overall, I cannot recommend this game enough for anyone who is curious about what BeamNG.drive is all about. Even if you're not a racing fan or car person, I guarantee there's atleast several hours of fun here to be had just fiddling around with the different cars physics and crash models.

If you're searching for a realistic sim racer: This should not be your game of choice. No mutliplayer without mods and not even slipstream without mods.

It is customisable to the point of OCD. It's better looking than Assetto Corsa. It has a jaw droppingly cool single player campaign with the kinds of customisation options every racer dreams about. It has missions, challenges, time trials, etc.
The only things missing are proper multiplayer, lobbies, slightly better car-feel to the handling, and...nope, that's it.

Get it, even if you never devote that much time to it compared with your main driving games you will still be blown away by the amount of sheer STUFF in this game.
